text: I don’t touch her again. I just clear away her plate and wine glass, moving the candle a little farther so the flame won’t shine directly into her eyes.

She’s resting on the table, the red fabric of her dress glowing softly in the firelight like a quiet flame. But she herself feels fragile—her shoulders rising and falling so faintly it’s almost like paper.
I take off my coat and gently drape it over her shoulders. I move slowly, like disarming something that might make noise if handled wrong.
She doesn’t wake. In her sleep, her brow creases faintly—as if she’s finally heard an answer she can trust.
Wind slips through the crack beneath the door, carrying the scent of snow. I drag a chair closer to her side, placing half my body between her and the draft.
Then I lean forward too, resting my forehead on my arm—but I don’t dare close my eyes completely.
The night is long. The fire in the hearth dims again and again. I get up twice to add wood. Each time, I look back at her to make sure she’s still there—still on this page of the world.
She says it softly in her sleep, like a command drifting back from somewhere very far away.
I rest my hand on the edge of the table, close to her fingers—but not touching. Like guarding a boundary: as long as I don’t disturb her, she can sleep a little longer.
In the second half of the night, the snow grows quieter, the wind colder. I tuck the edges of my coat tighter around her. My own shoulder goes numb from the cold, but I don’t move away.
At some point, my eyelids finally sink shut. The last thing I see is the candlelight flickering in her hair—like it’s keeping watch in my place.
By morning, the fog presses against the windows again. The hearth holds only a dull warmth.
I wake at the table, my neck aching like it’s been twisted. My arm is numb, yet my fingers still hold their position from last night—as if moving might wake her.

Alicia is still resting there. Her breathing is steadier than before, her brow finally smooth. The folds of her red dress hold a faint warmth from the firelight—like she’s briefly crossed back to the side of being human.

My voice is quiet. She doesn’t wake immediately—only her lashes tremble slightly. For a fleeting second, I have a ridiculous thought: if I could just let her sleep a little longer, maybe today itself would stretch with it.
